reverseZones.title: Reverse Zones for CIDR Delegation
reverseZones.description: Minimal reverse DNS zones needed to properly delegate IPv4 and IPv6 CIDR blocks with practical examples.

overview.title: What are Reverse Zones?
overview.content:
Reverse DNS zones map IP addresses back to domain names using special domains (.in-addr.arpa for IPv4, .ip6.arpa for IPv6). When you're delegated a CIDR block, you need to create the corresponding reverse zones for proper DNS operation.

Reverse zones are essential for mail servers, logging, security tools, and network troubleshooting.

delegation.title: How Reverse Delegation Works
delegation.content:
Your ISP or RIR delegates reverse DNS authority for your IP blocks to your DNS servers. You then create the reverse zones and populate them with PTR records that map IP addresses to hostnames.

The delegation happens at specific boundaries that align with IP addressing hierarchy.

classfullBoundaries.delegation: Usually handled by RIRs, not end users

classfullBoundaries.description: Class C network - most common delegation

classlessDelegation.solution: Use CNAME delegation with bit notation

classlessDelegation.problem: Quarter of /24, doesn't align with octets

practicalExamples.delegation: ISP delegates entire /24 reverse zone to customer DNS
ISP delegates both zones or uses automation

practicalExamples.management: Create master zone, delegate individual /64s as needed

ipv4Example.zoneFile:
$TTL 86400
2.0.192.in-addr.arpa.    IN    SOA    ns1.example.com. hostmaster.example.com. (
                                2024010101  ; serial
                                3600        ; refresh
                                1800        ; retry
                                1209600     ; expire
                                86400 )     ; minimum

                         IN    NS     ns1.example.com.
                         IN    NS     ns2.example.com.

1                        IN    PTR    mail.example.com.
10                       IN    PTR    web.example.com.
50                       IN    PTR    server1.example.com.
100                      IN    PTR    workstation.example.com.
explanation: Zone name is network reversed + in-addr.arpa
SOA record defines zone authority and parameters
NS records point to authoritative name servers
PTR records map IP to hostname (just last octet for /24)

ipv6Example.zoneFile:
$TTL 86400
4.3.2.1.8.b.d.0.1.0.0.2.ip6.arpa. IN SOA ns1.example.com. hostmaster.example.com. (
                                2024010101  ; serial
                                3600        ; refresh
                                1800        ; retry
                                1209600     ; expire
                                86400 )     ; minimum

                         IN    NS     ns1.example.com.
                         IN    NS     ns2.example.com.

; Delegate /64 subnets
0.0.0.0                  IN    NS     ns1.example.com.
0.0.0.0                  IN    NS     ns2.example.com.

1.0.0.0                  IN    NS     ns1.example.com.
1.0.0.0                  IN    NS     ns2.example.com.
explanation: Zone name is full prefix in nibble format + ip6.arpa
Each hex digit becomes separate label in reverse
Much longer zone names than IPv4

Each department manages their own PTR records

issues.diagnosis: Use dig -x [ip] to test reverse resolution
issues.solution: Check delegation, verify DNS server config, add PTR records

causes: Missing PTR record for mail server IP
issues.diagnosis: Check mail server logs, test PTR record
issues.solution: Create PTR record that matches mail server hostname

issues.diagnosis: Verify zone name format, test with dig -x
issues.solution: Double-check nibble format, verify IPv6 DNS configuration

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
practices: Always create reverse zones for your allocated IP blocks
Ensure PTR records match forward DNS (A/AAAA records)
Use consistent naming conventions for reverse records
Monitor reverse DNS resolution for important services
Automate PTR record creation/updates where possible
Test reverse lookups from multiple external locations
Keep reverse zone serial numbers updated when making changes

quickReference.title: Quick Reference
quickReference.keyRule: IPv4 reverse zones reverse the octets (192.0.2.0/24 → 2.0.192.in-addr.arpa). IPv6 reverse zones reverse the nibbles (2001:db8::/32 → 8.b.d.0.1.0.0.2.ip6.arpa).
essentialRecords: PTR records (actual IP to name mappings)
Match PTR with forward A/AAAA records
